tossups.question: A factor required for this process is targeted by an antibody found in almost 100 percent of patients with mixed connective tissue disease. In Drosophila, the protein “suppressor of white apricot” is a regulator of this process, as are other members of the SR family. A complex involved in this process contains the Smith antigens. This process requires a donor site, an acceptor site, and a branch point, the last of which is required to form a lariat (“LAIR-ee-it”). In some substrates in which this process occurs without protein (*) catalysis, it proceeds via two successive transesterification steps. Small nuclear ribo-nucleo-proteins, or snRNPs (“snurps”) catalyze this process, which can produce alternative isoforms of a single protein. For 10 points, name this process in which introns are removed to form a mature mRNA.
tossups.answer: RNA splicing [accept alternative splicing] <EM, Biology: Genetics/Cell>

tossups.question: A character in this location imagines his wife stroking his tattered coat and often wonders what his coworker Gomez is saying about him. While in this location, one character calls another a “well-trained dog who comes when his mistress calls” and persistently describes him as a coward. Imagery associated with this location is dismissed as “Old wives’ tales!” by a character who mutters “Well, well, let’s get on with it….” While here, a woman recalls how she dropped her (*) baby from a balcony into a lake. This location is tended by a valet with no eyelids and decorated with furniture in the Second Empire style in a play that features the characters Estelle and Inès (“ee-NESS”). For 10 points, Garcin (“gar-SAN”) declares what place “is other people” at the end of the best-known play by Jean-Paul Sartre?
tossups.answer: hell [accept descriptive answers such as the setting or room of No Exit] <RK, Drama>

tossups.question: In the Theaetetus (“thee-uh-TEE-tuss”), Socrates claims to be abusing an “orphan” in repeatedly refuting a dead philosopher’s statement about [emphasize] this entity, such as by asking why the distribution of wisdom is inequitable. A quip from Hermes Trismegistus to Asclepius about this entity is quoted in a tract that opens by recalling how Abdala the Saracen described this entity as “evocative of wonder,” and which was meant to introduce its author’s 900 Theses. In the (*) Politics, Aristotle claims that this entity is defined by existing within a polis. A Renaissance argument for the pursuit of knowledge is presented in Pico della Mirandola’s “oration” on this entity’s “dignity.” Protagoras claimed that the “measure of all things” was, for 10 points, what entity that Aristotle also called a “rational animal”?
tossups.answer: man [or humanity; or homo sapiens; accept Oration on the Dignity of Man or “man is the measure of all things”] <WA, Phil/Thought>

tossups.question: This religion was practiced by a hereditary class of artisans known for their silver work called falasha. The Lemba people claim descent from followers of this religion. After marrying a follower of this religion named Zenobis, a queen legendarily adopted it and destroyed the Axumite Empire. Its followers stored thousands of documents in a cellar called the Genizah (“guh-NEE-zah”) in (*) Cairo. The Saadi dynasty of Morocco welcomed thousands of followers of this religion called marranos. A 1990 airlift allowed most of this religion’s Ethiopian followers to flee the country. Many Mizrahi followers of this religion lived in North Africa. For 10 points, name this religion practiced by Sephardic people who fled Spain, as well as Ethiopia’s Beta Israel people and Ashkenazis.
tossups.answer: Judaism [or Jewish religion] <JM, World History>

tossups.question: Jessie Little Doe Baird established a revitalization program for a language spoken in this state inspired by the success of Hawaiian “language nests.” The professors C. T. Huang and Ray Jackendoff were graduate students in this state, where they helped defend their advisor’s theories against the attacks of the “four horsemen” of linguistics. This state’s largest city is where the word (*) “wicked” is most commonly used as an intensifier, and has a traditionally non-rhotic accent that prominently uses the broad “a.” The unusually high rate of hereditary deafness on one island in this state led the islanders to develop their own sign language. The Wampanoag (“wam-puh-NOH-ug”) language is spoken in, for 10 points, what state where Noam Chomsky has taught at an “Institute of Technology” in Cambridge since 1955?
tossups.answer: Massachusetts [accept Massachusetts Institute of Technology] (The sign language is Martha’s Vineyard Sign Language.) <JM, Social Science: Linguistics>

tossups.question: This bandleader remixed the Scritti Politti song “Perfect Way” on the first of his collaboration albums with Marcus Miller, which was criticized for its use of synthesizers and drum machines. That album, Tutu, followed up on an album by this musician that was finally released in September 2019, titled Rubberband. A third album by this jazz artist begins with a chord held on the organ by Joe Zawinul (“ZAH-vih-null”) on the track “Shhh/Peaceful.” (*) Wayne Shorter stayed on from this musician’s Second Great Quintet to work on that first fusion album by this musician, titled In A Silent Way. Earlier, this bandleader worked with arranger Gil Evans on an album that included “Freddie Freeloader” and “So What.” For 10 points, name this bandleader and trumpeter on the album Kind of Blue.
tossups.answer: Miles Davis <WA, Other Arts: Music>

tossups.question: The last line of a novel by this author describes how a woman’s “diarrhea persisted through the twenty-sixth.” In another of this author’s novels, a character known as “old man” treats his younger mistress like a doll, inspiring his son-in-law protagonist to take up an interest in puppet theatre. This author created a waitress who attends lessons in English and music to become a “modern girl” like Mary Pickford in his novel (*) Naomi (“NOW-mee”). In a novel by this author, the euphemism “going to Suma” refers to an affair carried on by Misako during her deteriorating marriage with Kaname. Another novel by this author centers on Yukiko’s struggles to find a husband with the help of her siblings Taeko (“ta-EH-ko”) and Itakura. For 10 points, name this Japanese author of Some Prefer Nettles and The Makioka Sisters.
tossups.answer: Jun’ichirō Tanizaki <AR, Long Fiction>

tossups.question: Over 1000 animals were thrown in a massive fox-tossing contest held in this city by one of its leaders, who founded a museum in this city called the Green Vault. After a 1685 fire, Matthäus Pöppelmann (“ma-TAY-us purple-mon”) helped rebuild this city by designing its Zwinger Palace. While fleeing Frederick the Great because he couldn’t actually create gold, the alchemist Johann Bottger discovered porcelain and began a factory near this city at Meissen (“MICE-in”). Bottger’s experiments were supervised by (*) Augustus the Strong, who led a state based in this city before becoming king of Poland. Arthur Harris of the Royal Air Force supported an attack on this city that Winston Churchill called a “mere act of terror.” For 10 points, name this capital of Saxony, a German city whose firebombing by the Allies was condemned as an atrocity during World War II.
tossups.answer: Dresden <NC, European History>

tossups.question: Codenomicon marketed one of these things in an open-source encryption protocol library in which a server calls memcpy (“MEM-copy”) with bp, pl, and a third parameter copied from the TLS handshake request. MITRE’s (“miter’s”) taxonomy and database of these things assigns unique identifiers prefixed by CWE and CVE. Google founded Project Zero in 2014, when many of them started being branded with logos, after one of them in OpenSSL involved failing to bounds-check when reading a (*) buffer. Pentests and fuzzers help find these things. High bounties reward “white hats” for responsibly disclosing them. Until vendors become aware, these things are called zero-days. Intel processors could not easily patch Spectre and Meltdown, severe examples of these things, via software update, unlike Heartbleed. For 10 points, identify these software issues taken advantage of by malware.
tossups.answer: security vulnerabilities [or exploits or security bugs or security holes; accept zero-days until read; prompt on bugs, issues, weaknesses, defects, flaws, anomalies, threats, attacks, cyberattacks, breaches, or hacks by asking “what general impact do they have?” and accept answers like “weakens security” or “vulnerable to attack”; prompt on specific types of bugs, such as software bugs or buffer over-read or memory leaks, by asking “can you be less specific?”; do not accept or prompt on “glitches” or “viruses” or “malware” or “data breaches”] <OL, Computer Science>

tossups.question: This man is the primary prophet of a religion whose scriptures are called the “Great Treasury” or Ginza Rba (“geen-ZAH ruh-BAH”) and describe several emanations of God, including Abatur. This man, whom Muslims believe was buried in Nablus, is the main prophet of a Gnostic religion from Iraq called Mandaeism (“man-DAY-ism”). Though nobody in his family had this man’s name, his father wrote it on a tablet after being (*) deprived of speech during the three days before this man was born. This man, who performed the act for which he is most famous at the village of Bethabara, was born to Elizabeth and Zechariah and is referred to as the “forerunner” of Jesus. For 10 points, name this figure who acquired his sobriquet from dunking Jesus in the River Jordan.
tossups.answer: John the Baptist [or Yahya; or Yochanan] <WA, Religion>

tossups.question: A 1939 strike in Southeast Missouri among this profession led to the establishment of a village named for it. The biography All God’s Dangers describes Nate Shaw’s economic success as a member of this profession and arrest after joining a union of its members. People in this profession who had formed a union were targeted in the Elaine Massacre. Walker (*) Evans took a series of photographs of three families of this profession as part of a book co-authored with James Agee. After the Civil War, vagrancy laws forced many freedmen to adopt this profession or face jail time, and thus it became the primary occupation of African-Americans in the South. For 10 points, name this profession made up of farmers who were forced to give up portions of their harvests.
tossups.answer: sharecropping [or word forms; accept tenant farming; prompt on farming or agriculture] <JM, US History>

tossups.question: Subrahmanyan Chandrashekar proposed that this property could be found on the limbs of rapidly rotating binary stars with purely electron-scattering stellar atmospheres. The CMBR has two forms of this property resulting from either Thomson scattering in a heterogenous plasma or from gravitational waves from inflation. Those two forms of this property are known as E- and B-modes. The angle at which this property is transmitted perfectly between two (*) media with no reflection is equal to the arctangent of the ratio of their indices of refraction and is named for Brewster. This property, which comes in linear, circular and elliptical varieties, is employed by sunglasses to reduce glare. For 10 points, name this property that describes waves that have a particular direction of oscillation.
tossups.answer: polarization [do not accept or prompt on “polarizability”] <RN, Physics>

tossups.question: A nude sculpture titled for this profession by Takashi Murakami depicts its erect subject holding a long stream of ejaculate. An ad depicting a member of this profession was reappropriated into the 1.2-million-dollar photograph Untitled by Richard Prince. N. C. Wyeth painted a magazine cover for the Saturday Evening Post depicting a man of this profession in front of a setting sun. Men of this profession are the subject of an epic revisionist film by Sam (*) Peckinpah titled The Wild Bunch. An illustration depicting a member of this profession for a Century Magazine article by Theodore Roosevelt became the basis for a bronze sculpture depicting a member of this profession rearing backwards. For 10 points, what profession is the subject of Frederic Remington’s sculpture Bronco Buster?
tossups.answer: cowboys [prompt on horsemen] <RK, Painting/Sculpture>

tossups.question: Dan Gibson is the best known exponent of a theory that Muhammad was actually from this city rather than Mecca. This city, called Rekem by its inhabitants, was the namesake of a Roman province whose capital was moved to Bosra after Trajan’s capture of this city. Believing that he would find Aaron’s tomb there, Johann Ludwig Burckhardt became the first post-classical European to visit this city in 1812. (*) Aretas IV, a king who ruled from this city, is best known as the namesake of a building in it known as his “treasury” even though it is likely his tomb. This city was established as the capital of the Nabataean Kingdom partially to profit off of trade in incense from Yemen. For 10 points, name this ancient “rose city” in modern Jordan.
tossups.answer: Petra [accept Rekem until read] <JM, Ancient/Archaeology>

tossups.question: One of these objects created by Sandro Valera is destroyed by a woman named Reno for an art project in the Bonneville Salt Flats in Rachel Kushner’s 2013 novel The Flamethrowers. A book centering on these objects refers to the narrator prior to electroshock therapy using the name Phaedrus, and put forth the author’s “Metaphysics of Quality.” A medical student jokingly nicknames one of these objects “La Poderosa,” or “The Mighty One,” in a memoir about his journey across (*) South America with Alberto Granado. A philosophical 1974 novel was inspired by its author Robert M. Pirsig’s trip with his son Chris from Minnesota to San Francisco in one of these vehicles, which title some “diaries” by Che Guevera. For 10 points, Robert Pirsig’s book pairs Zen with the art of maintaining what vehicles?
tossups.answer: motorcycles [or motorbikes; or choppers; or hogs] <RK, Misc Lit>

tossups.question: One of these dances in G minor by Franz Liszt begins with a steady crescendo as the left and right hand play presto triplets rising from the piano’s lowest register, and is part of a supplement to the second suite of Years of Pilgrimage. The name of this dance supposedly originated after performers disturbed a priest of the church of St. Magnus. This dance is used in the finale of Schubert’s String Quartet No. 14, “Death and the Maiden.” This dance in 6/8 (“six-eight”) time, and the related (*) saltarello, are found in the finale of Felix Mendelssohn’s Symphony No. 4. This dance may be named for a city in Apulia whose women performed it furiously to sweat venom out of their pores. For 10 points, name this frenzied Italian dance whose name indicates that it could supposedly cure a hairy spider’s bite.
tossups.answer: tarantella [or tarantelle; or tarantello] <WA, Classical/Opera>

tossups.question: This letter is found in the prefix of the name of a molecule used as the starting point of heme and chlorophyll biosynthesis, called aminolevulenic acid, or ALA. Lactones and lactase with this letter preceding their name contain 6-membered heterocyclic rings. Lanthanide-based reagents such as EuFOD are used to improve the resolution of a quantity symbolized by this letter. That quantity denoted by this letter, which is often calibrated against a trimethylsilane standard, is called the (*) chemical shift and is vital in NMR. The addition of heat in a chemical reaction is symbolized by writing this letter over the reaction arrow. The lowercase version of this letter is used to represent partial charges in polar bonds. For 10 points, name this Greek letter whose uppercase version represents the change in quantities like free energy and entropy.
tossups.answer: delta <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.question: For use in “The Dry Salvages (“sal-VAY-jizz”),” T. S. Eliot simplified this poem’s phrase “the deep / Moans round with many voices,” after calling it “too poetical” in his essay “Dante.” In this poem, the speaker notes “how dull it is” to “rust unburnish’d, not to shine in use!” and intends to “drink / Life to the lees.” In the second of this poem’s three stanzas, the speaker introduces his son, who “works his work” and is given the (*) “sceptre and the isle.” This poem opens with its speaker near a “still hearth (“harth”), among these barren crags, / Match’d with an aged wife.” This dramatic monologue ends with the speaker describing himself as “Made weak by time and fate, but strong in will / To strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield.” For 10 points, name this poem by Alfred, Lord Tennyson, spoken by a king of Ithaca.
tossups.answer: “Ulysses” <NC, Poetry>

tossups.question: Herodotus states that the Scythians sent one of these animals along with a bird, a mouse, and five arrows to Darius as a threatening gift. In one of Aesop’s fables, a stork begins devouring these animals after they pray to Zeus to receive a king. A mock-epic falsely attributed to Homer describes a battle between these animals and mice. These animals exclaim “That’s right, Mr. Busybody, right!” in a work that begins as a god argues whether he should complain about an aching shoulder or a bellyache with his servant (*) Xanthias. These animals sing and mock Charon while he rows in that play, repeating the line “Brekekekex koax koax.” Dionysus tries to retrieve Euripides from the underworld in an Aristophanes play titled after, for 10 points, what croaking amphibians?
tossups.answer: frogs [or batrachoi or ranae] <RR, Myths/Legends>

tossups.question: The traditional costume of men in this country is a toga-like cloth whose name means “holy,” called the jard. Dozens of this country’s people still die each year from landmines in its Nafusa Mountains and other regions. To honor the photojournalist Tim Hetherington, this country’s city of Ajdabiya (“ahj-da-BEE-ya”) named a square after him. Sabha (“SEB-ha”), the largest city within this country’s poor (*) Fezzan region, is one of many cities containing newly opened slave markets in the past decade. One of the two major factions in this country’s ongoing civil war is headquartered at Tobruk. This country re-adopted its traditional red, green, and black flag in 2011, replacing an all-green one. For 10 points, name this country whose non-Tobruk government is located in Tripoli.
tossups.answer: Libya [or State of Libya] <WA, Geography>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: An essay from Edward Said’s (“sa-EED’s”) Culture and Imperialism examines the “dead silence” that occurs after the protagonist mentions this place’s support by slave labor on sugar plantations in Antigua. For 10 points each:
answers: Fanny Burney [or Frances Burney] <RK, Long Fiction>
parts: Name this estate owned by Thomas Bertram. At the age of 10, Bertram’s niece Fanny Price moves to this title estate of an 1814 novel.
This author, the subject of many letters by her niece Fanny Knight, depicted the heroine Fanny Price in her novel Mansfield Park.

Austen took the title Pride and Prejudice from the final chapter of the novel Evelina. This writer with the first name Fanny decried the “vile poem” by George Huddesford that outed her as the anonymous author of Evelina.

bonuses.leadin: The universal principles of this religious tradition’s teachings were emphasized by S. N. Goenka (“go-EN-ka”), a teacher born in Burma, a country where it is dominant. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this orthodox tradition of Buddhism that originated in Sri Lanka. It is contrasted with the Mahayana and Vajrayana traditions.

The name of this type of meditation practiced by Theravada Buddhists is the Pali word for the insight that it seeks to cultivate. Western teachers of this type of meditation, such as Sharon Salzberg, contributed to the mindfulness movement.
Members of this esoteric religious society founded by Helena Blavatsky started many lay Buddhist organizations in Sri Lanka that promoted vipassana.

bonuses.leadin: In the common “first-price” variety of these events, the price of the item in question is bid up until it is sold to the highest bidder. For 10 points each:
answers: Netherlands [accept Holland; accept Dutch auction or Dutch disease]
reserve price [or reservation price] <WA, Social Science: Econ>
parts: Name these events in which items are sold publicly.

In a type of auction named for this non-British country, an item’s price is instead repeatedly lowered until a bidder is willing to pay. In economics, this country’s namesake “disease” is an alternate name for the so-called “resource curse.”

This term refers to the minimum price at which an item may be sold at a Dutch auction. By the revenue equivalence theorem, first- and second-price auctions will have identical outcomes if this price is the same for both.

bonuses.leadin: Pyoderma gangrenosum, aphthous ulcers, and iritis are some of the non-GI manifestations of this disease, which causes chronic diarrhea. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this form of inflammatory bowel disease whose skip lesions are contrasted with the continuous superficial inflammations that distinguish it from ulcerative colitis.
One of the more dangerous effects of Crohn’s disease is the formulation of these abnormal connections between two compartments in the body. Women with Crohn’s may suffer from rectovaginal ones.
Crohn’s disease increases the risk of colon cancer, which is why people with longstanding Crohn’s should undergo this procedure often. In this procedure, a camera is used to find polyps (“PAW-lips”).

bonuses.leadin: When asked whether he was aware that the literacy tests he wanted were discriminatory, this man responded “Discrimination! Why that is exactly what we propose.” For 10 points each:
answers: investment banks AND commercial banks <ML, US History>
parts: Name this supporter of segregation who represented Virginia in both the Senate and the House. He was one of the two namesakes of a Banking Reform Act that created the FDIC.
The Glass–Steagall Act was repealed under this president, who used the slogan “it’s the economy, stupid” in his re-election campaign and signed the North American Free Trade Agreement.

Specifically, the Glass–Steagall Act separated these two types of banks. One of these types of banks mainly focuses on securities and M&A transactions, while the other focuses on consumer services and deposits.

bonuses.leadin: In a painting of this title by François Boucher (“boo-SHAY”), a woman traces out an image of one of the several putti in front of her. For 10 points each:
answers: The Allegory of Painting [or The Art of Painting or Painter in His Studio]
parts: Give this title of a Dutch painting in which a blue-and-orange curtain is pulled back at the left, revealing a scene in which a model in a blue dress stands in front of a map.
This Dutch artist of The Milkmaid and Girl with a Pearl Earring painted that Allegory of Painting.

This artist is shown intently focused on a canvas, wearing a blue garment and a pendant in the form of a mask to symbolize imitation, in a Self-Portrait as the Allegory of Painting. In 2018, the National Gallery in London purchased one of this artist’s self-portraits as a saint from Alexandria.

bonuses.leadin: Under this ruler, the Statute of Artificers empowered judges to fix wages throughout the country. For 10 points each:
answers: Elizabeth I [accept Good Queen Bess; accept Gloriana; prompt on the Virgin Queen; prompt on Bess]
Ottoman Empire [prompt on Turkey] <ML, European History>
parts: Name this ruler who made the face value of the coin equal to the worth of the coin in England. This 16th-century female English ruler faced plots like the Babington and Throckmorton plots.
Elizabeth I imposed a punitive tax on this beverage. Edward IV executed his brother, the Duke of Clarence, by drowning him in this specific beverage.

The first English ambassador to this polity was sent by Elizabeth I and was named William Harborne. Dragomans were European ambassadors to this polity, whose Topkapi Palace was often called the Sublime Porte.

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist describes himself as a “man of two faces” after fleeing this country to Los Angeles, where he spies on “the General” in the 2016 novel The Sympathizer. For 10 points each:
answers: Vietnam [or Việt Nam; or Socialist Republic of Vietnam]
aubade (“oh-BOD”) [accept “Aubade with Burning City”] (The other poem is “Aubade” by Philip Larkin.) <JM, Misc Lit>
parts: Name this country. Paul Berlin chases a man who tries to walk from this modern-day country to Paris in the novel Going After Cacciato (“ka-CHA-toh”).
Going After Cacciato was written by this author, who fictionalized his time in the Vietnam War in the collection The Things They Carried.

A poem by Ocean Vuong (“VOO-ung”) about the Fall of Saigon is titled for this poetic genre “with Burning City.” The speaker of another poem in this genre declares “I work all day, and get half-drunk at night.”

bonuses.leadin: Mae West’s outfits often included black examples of these articles of clothing, which helped enhance her status as a sex symbol in the 1930s. For 10 points each:
answers: Diane von Fürstenberg [or Diane of Fürstenberg; or Diane Simone Michelle Halfin; or DVF] <WA, Other Arts: Misc>
parts: Give these articles of clothing. One made of meat was worn by Lady Gaga at the 2010 MTV Music Awards.

This fashion house designed the green dress printed with leaf and bamboo patterns that Jennifer Lopez wore to the 2000 Grammys. This fashion house’s namesake was murdered in 1997 by the spree killer Andrew Cunahan.
This Belgian-born designer is best known for her iconic, body-hugging wrap dresses, which have a V-shaped neckline and are often considered major expressions of sexual liberation.

bonuses.leadin: A property of these objects is often demonstrated by the “plate trick” or “Balinese cup dance,” in which a hand is rotated twice before returning to its original position. For 10 points each:
answers: spinors (“spinners”) [accept Dirac spinors; prompt on vectors; prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, quaternions]
fermions (They are described by Fermi–Dirac statistics.) <WA, Physics>
parts: Name these mathematical objects that transform into their inverses under a rotation of 360 degrees, and only return to their initial state after a rotation of 720 degrees. SU(2) (“S-U-two”) is identical to one of their symmetry groups.

The Pauli matrices, which form a basis for a set of these numbers, are used to describe how spinors behave under rotations and boosts. These numbers are a four-dimensional analogue of the complex numbers.

Spinors are used in Paul Dirac’s namesake relativistic equation for this class of spin one-half particles. These particles are described by statistics named for Paul Dirac and their namesake Italian physicist.

bonuses.leadin: Richard Rorty, who popularized this phrase in the Anglophone tradition, used it to title a series of “essays in philosophical method” exploring the birth of analytic philosophy. For 10 points each:
answers: linguistic turn [accept The Linguistic Turn: Essays in Philosophical Method]
parts: Give this two-word phrase that denotes a shift in philosophical focus away from absolute idealism to the connections between words and reality, as seen in the work of Gottlob Frege (“FRAY-guh”).
Rorty was an analytic philosopher before founding a “new” version of this American philosophical tradition. Its adherents, such as William James, emphasized applying practical tests to ideas.
Rorty turned his attention to pragmatism after reading the works of Wilfred Sellars and this other analytic philosopher, who discussed the structure–content distinction in “Two Dogmas of Empiricism.”

bonuses.leadin: An elegiac couplet typically consists of a line in this meter followed by a line in pentameter. For 10 points each:
answers: dactylic hexameter [prompt on hexameter; prompt on epic meter or heroic hexameter]
parts: Name this poetic meter often described as “epic” for its use in such works as the Iliad, Odyssey, and Aeneid.
Theseus’s abandonment of Ariadne is depicted in a long ekphrastic passage of this epyllion in dactylic hexameter that centers on the wedding of Peleus and Thetis. It is the longest poem by Catullus.
Catullus 51 mostly translates a fragment in which this poet described a lover who seems “to be equal to a god.” Both poems use the stanza named for this female poet from Lesbos.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Baroque composer and teacher Johann Adolph Hasse (“HAH-suh”), for 10 points each.
answers: Frederick the Great [or Frederick II or Friedrich II; prompt on Frederick]
Kapellmeister [prompt on chapel master; prompt on music director]
Naples [or Napoli; prompt on Neapolitan opera or Neapolitan sixth chord] <WA, Classical/Opera>
parts: It is thought that several of Hasse’s flute sonatas were written for this talented flute player, a Prussian monarch who gave J. S. Bach the theme for his Musical Offering.

Beginning in 1730, Hasse held this title in Dresden. This German title designated the in-house composers of churches and princes, and it was held by J. S. Bach at the court of Leopold, Prince of Anhalt-Köthen.

Hasse was taught by Alessandro Scarlatti, who originated this city’s namesake school of opera. This city names a first-inversion major triad built on the lowered second scale degree, sometimes called a type of sixth chord.

bonuses.leadin: One company with this name was founded by the staunchly positivist Sephardic Pereire (“pay-RAIR”) brothers, and was accused by Marx of “trying to make Napoleon III the supreme dictator of France’s industry.” For 10 points each:
answers: Crédit Mobilier [or Société Générale du Crédit Mobilier]
parts: Name this bank that made massive investments in railroad construction before going bust during the Panic of 1873. An admirer of that company, Thomas Durant, named an American bank he founded after that company.

Crédit Mobilier of America paid bribes to a number of Republican politicians during this president’s scandal-plagued administration. This president earlier served as the chief Union general during the Civil War.
In another railroad-finance affair, this Canadian prime minister lost an election to the Liberal Party after favoring the Canadian Pacific Railroad over its competitors in the Pacific Scandal.

bonuses.leadin: These mixtures are designated positive or negative based on whether their boiling point is less than or greater than the boiling points of its constituents. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these mixtures that cannot be separated by distillation because, when boiled, their vapor has the same composition as the parent mixture.
Azeotropes deviate from this law, which states that the vapor pressure of the components of a mixture is equal to the vapor pressure of each individual component times its mole fraction.

This apparatus can be used to separate azeotropes, such as a solution of 95-percent ethanol and 5-percent water, because it can continuously remove water generated in a reaction. This apparatus is used in the Fischer esterification to remove water.

bonuses.leadin: In 1876, the Qing (“ching”) government produced a report on Chinese people who were kidnapped to work harvesting this crop. For 10 points each:
answers: Chincha Islands [or Islas Chinchas] <JM, World History>
parts: Name this crop that was largely produced in the Caribbean by Chinese and Indian indentured laborers after the abolition of slavery. Demand for this crop increased as the working class began to use it to flavor their tea.

The Chinese workers who testified to the Qing commission were largely kidnapped in this port city, which has since become an international gambling hub. The Patuá (“pa-TWAH”) creole language is spoken in this city, which is also known as Aomen.

Kidnapped Chinese workers were also kept in slave-like conditions on these Peruvian islands in order to harvest guano. Spain seized these islands in 1864, which prompted a war in which Chile and Peru fought to take them back.

bonuses.leadin: Livy’s account of the myth of Virginia in his History of Rome inspired this author’s play Emilia Galotti. For 10 points each:
answers: Jewish [accept The Jew of Malta; prompt on Hebrew]
bourgeois (“boorzh-WAH”) [or bourgeois tragedy; accept The Bourgeois Gentleman or Le Bourgeois gentilhomme] <AR, Drama>
parts: Name this German author who retold the “parable of the three rings” in his play Nathan the Wise.
The title character of Lessing’s Nathan the Wise, who was inspired by Moses Mendelssohn, is of this ethnicity. Christopher Marlowe wrote a play about a Maltese person of this ethnicity named Barabas.

Lessing’s Miss Sara Simpson is considered to be an early example of a form of tragedy described by this adjective. This adjective partially titles a “comedy-ballet” about Monsieur Jourdain (“zhoor-DAN”), who hires “masters” in philosophy, music, dancing, and fencing to become a gentleman.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Renaissance polymath Athanasius Kircher (“KEER-kur”), for 10 points each.
answers: cabinet of curiosities [accept wonder rooms or Kunstkammer or Wunderkammer; prompt on rooms; do not accept or prompt on “cabinets”] <WA, Other Academic>
parts: Kircher claimed to have deciphered this sacred Egyptian writing system, which was more complicated than Demotic script. His translations were wrong, though, so we had to wait until the Rosetta Stone was found.

Kircher’s treatise on geology, Mundus Subterraneus, includes several drawings of this island off the coast of Sicily. This volcanic island names a type of intermittent, brilliant red eruption of molten lava.

Kircher assembled a famous example of these eclectic collections, which contained small artworks and ethnographic items from all around the world. Another of these collections was assembled by the Danish physician Ole Worm (“OH-luh wurm”).

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the extremely inscrutable work of mathematician Shinichi Mochizuki, for 10 points each.
parts: Mochizuki proved a conjecture named for this mathematician in anabelian (“ann-uh-BEEL-ee-in”) geometry. This French-German mathematician wrote a textbook abbreviated EGA, which set the foundations of algebraic geometry.
Inter-universal Teichmüller theory is a result of Mochizuki’s work in arithmetic geometry, which combines algebraic geometry with this field of math that studies the properties of the integers.
Each point in a Teichmüller space is an isomorphism class of surfaces named for this mathematician. This man’s sums generalize the rectangular approximation methods for calculating an integral.

bonuses.leadin: When this figure was killed by the Swallow people, his wife became the murderous Changing Bear woman. For 10 points each:
answers: creation of humanity [accept answers that indicate that the first humans are being made]
parts: Name this figure from Native American tales who tried to stay up all night to win the best bow. While juggling his eyeballs to impress some girls, this canine trickster created the star Arcturus.

In Native American traditions, Coyote performed this action by kicking a ball of mud. In Norse myth, this action was performed when the gods imbued two pieces of driftwood named Ask and Embla with gifts.
In many Lakota stories, a shapeshifting trickster named Iktomi who normally takes this animal form is the accomplice of Coyote in his exploits.
